gmd:title.gco:CharacterString: 8 Kilometer Land Cover Product from the University of Maryland

gmd:alternateTitle.gco:CharacterString: Global land cover classifications at 8km spatial resolution: the use of training data derived from Landsat imagery in decision tree classifiers

gmd:individualName.gco:CharacterString: DeFries, R.S., Hansen, M., Townshend, J.R.G., and Sohlberg, R.

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: This summary is adapted from the Eight Kilometer Global Land Cover Project Document-Data Set Description web page, which may be found at the following URL: "http://glcf.umiacs.umd.edu/data/landcover/data.shtml". To develop improved methodologies for global land cover classifications as well as to provide global land cover products for immediate use in global change research, University of Maryland's Global Land Cover Facility (GLCF) and NASA have employed the NASA/NOAA Pathfinder Land (PAL) data set with a spatial resolution of 8 km. This data set has a length of record of 14 years (1981-1994), providing the ability to test the stability of classification algorithms. Furthermore, this data set includes red, infrared, and thermal bands in addition to the Normalized Difference Vegetation Index (NDVI). Inclusion of these additional bands improves discrimination between cover types. To identify the pixels to be used for training of the 8 km AVHRR Pathfinder data, the investigators collected a total of over 200 high resolution scenes of which they were confident of which cover type occurs. Most of the scenes used were acquired by the Landsat Multispectral Scanner System (MSS), and a few by Landsat Thematic Mapper and the LISS (Linear Imaging Self-Scanning Sensor). Of the initial 200 scenes, the investigators considered 156 suitable for interpretation. Scenes were considered unsuitable if haze or poor quality data obscured the scene or if the cover types in the scene could not be visually distinguished. For most scenes, the investigators aimed to identify only one cover type within the scene. It was possible, however, to identify more than one cover type in some scenes if croplands were visually identifiable based on the spatial patterns of fields or if vegetation maps showed the presence of clearly identifiable cover types. The second part of the study involved deriving a global land cover classififcation product. The product was derived by testing several metrics that describe the temporal dynamics of vegetation over an annual cycle. These metrics have the potential to be used as input variables to a global land cover classification. The tested metrics are based on 1) the ratio between surface temperature and NDVI, 2) seasonal metrics derived from the NDVI temporal profile such as length of growing season, 3) a rule-based approach that determines cover type through a series of hierarchical trees based on surface temperature and NDVI values, and 4) annual mean, maximum, minimum, and amplitude values for all optical and thermal channels in the AVHRR Pathfinder Land (PAL) data. These metrics were applied to 1984 PAL data at 8km resolution to derive a global land cover classification product using a decision tree classifier. This method was then applied to AVHRR data from other years and higher spatial resolutions. [ This document was provided by NASA's Global Change Master Directory. For more information on the source of this metadata please visit http://gcmd.nasa.gov/r/geoss/[GCMD]GLCF_GLC_8km ]

gmd:maintenanceNote.gco:CharacterString: Added ESIP homepage, May 18, 2000. Added LGRSS data center and revised Dr. Townshend's address, May 18, 2000.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: The dataset has high uncertainty. I would not recommend this data for land cover research.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: The data was not suitable for observation of land cover changes.

gvq:usage.gvq:usageDescription: I used this dataset to observe changes in land cover between 2000 and 2010 in South America region.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: The data for the Spain region (year 2013) was good. The metadata record is incomplete.

gvq:usage.gvq:usageDescription: The dataset was used to observe vegetation cover in Spain in 2013.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: It was planned to use this dataset to assess vegetation cover in the south region of Italy in 2009. The data for 2009 was extremely patchy and therefore unfit for purpose.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: Data for 2009 is very patchy, a lot of land coverage is missing or of very poor quality.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: Overall, the dataset provides good spatial and temporal coverage but the data is of high uncertainty. Metadata record is incomplete.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: Quality and lineage information is not available.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: The dataset provides good spatial and temporal coverage. Metadata record is empty.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: Metadata document is incomplete and quality information is not provided which makes it is hard to work with the data.

gvq:usage.gvq:usageDescription: I used this dataset to classify vegetation cover in Turkey for the year 2011.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: We discovered that data for 2006 is missing for most of the Germany region.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: No data for Germany region for the year 2006. Lack of metadata.

gvq:usage.gvq:usageDescription: We used this dataset to monitor changes in agricultural land use in Germany between 2005 and 2010.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: Very good temporal coverage for the Turkey region year 2010. Metadata record is incomplete.

gvq:usage.gvq:usageDescription: The data was used to observe farming land use in Turkey in 2010.

gvq:userComment.gvq:comment: The dataset was not appropriate for our application because of very high uncertainty and missing data for June - September 2012.

gvq:rating.gvq:justification: The data quality for Spain region in 2012 is very poor and metadata is nearly empty.

gvq:usage.gvq:usageDescription: The dataset was used for classification of land cover use in Spain in 2012.
